text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits new IRM 6.410.10, Learning and Education, Event Planning and Approval.
This is a new IRM section that provides guidance with respect to planning and approving mission-critical hosted and non-hosted training and events that come under the Treasury Directive 12-70 policy.
This IRM is intended to be used by all divisions and functions.

) Purpose: The purpose of this IRM is to provide guidance on the review and approval process for all Internal Revenue Service’s (IRS) hosted and non- hosted events. The IRS has a responsibility to act as a careful steward of taxpayer dollars, ensuring Federal funds are used for purposes that are priate, cost effective, and necessary to fulﬁll the core mission of the IRS. (
) Scope: This guidance applies to all events including, but not limited to ences, training, meetings, and others cited in this IRM; and covers planning, attendance, and approval requirements. (
) Audience: All operating divisions and business units. (

) Policy Owner: The HCO, Office of HR Strategy (OHRS), Policy and Audits Division, and Enterprise Training and Development (ETD) Division are sible for the administration, policy development and updates related to IRM
) Program Owner: ETD Servicewide Training and Event Management Office is responsible for the administration, policy development and updates related to IRM
) Primary Stakeholders: All Servicewide Learning and Education (SL&E) nizations are primary stakeholders. (

) Conference - A pre-arranged formal event with at least some of the following characteristics: designated participants, registration fee, a published substan- tive agenda, scheduled speakers or discussion panels on a topic, and involves IRS expenses (other than the salaries of attendees), such as expenses for re- freshments, meals, mementos, or travel (including transportation, lodging, or other expenses authorized under the FTR). A conference may include, but is not limited to, a retreat, convention, seminar or symposium. A conference typically is not a:

freshments, meals, mementos, or travel (including transportation, lodging, or other expenses authorized under the FTR). A conference may include, but is not limited to, a retreat, convention, seminar or symposium. A conference typically is not a: a. Routine operational meeting b. Law enforcement activity c. Mission-critical core function activity d. Response to an emergency or recovery activity related to a event e. Testing activity (including the planning, scheduling and conducting) f. Technical assistance/operational review site visit (
) Convention - A formal meeting of members or representatives of a or industry. (

) Event - An all-inclusive term to include a conference, meeting, training rence, award ceremony, or other similar gathering that involves expenses of the attendees, such as for travel, meals or refreshments. (
) Exempted event - An event submitted by the IRS and exempted from the
approval process. Also known as an excluded event. (

) Gift - Anything of monetary value, including transportation, local travel, and meals, whether provided in-kind, by purchase of a ticket, payment in advance, or reimbursement after the expense has been incurred. (
) Government facility - An IRS or other federal, state, or municipal building, room or facility. (

) Head of office - Any of the following IRS officials: IRS Commissioner; Commissioners; Division Commissioners; Chiefs; Chief Counsel; Chief of Directors reporting directly to the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioners; National Taxpayer Advocate. (

) Hosted/ Co-hosted event - An event arranged either in total or in part by IRS, Treasury, or another Treasury bureau, held in either a government or commercial facility, which may include both employees and non-employees attendees. The bureau provides or arranges for resources required to hold event. Internal order code - A data element in the Integrated Financial System that collects expenditure data for a speciﬁc project; used to track training event-related costs, and to track planning and expenditure data for projects within IFS. Light refreshments - Include, but are not limited to coffee, tea, milk, juice, drinks, ice cream, donuts, bagels, muffins, fruit, vegetable trays, cheese pretzels, cookies and chips.

) Meeting - A gathering of people with a purpose to discuss business which may include strategizing, planning, and resolving speciﬁc issues or of concern. (
) Memento - An object kept as a reminder of a person, place or event. This includes award trophies, speaker’s gifts, and any other item that commemo- rates an event. (
) Non-government facility - A building, room or space owned by a private- sector organization or entity. (
) Office - See Business unit. (
) Off-site - A location not on IRS premises, including other government and privately-owned buildings, such as hotels. (

) Promotional item - An article of merchandise used in marketing and nications programs. It is often branded with a logo or motto, used to an office, idea or image, and provided as a memento of an event. The may have an association with an event or be provided independently as a marketing tool. (
) Processing Lead Time - Amount of time required to complete the TD review and approval process. (
) Seminar - A lecture or presentation delivered to an audience on a topic or of topics that may be educational in nature. (

) Sponsored event - An event in which the IRS, Treasury or another bureau pays another entity to host an event, such as through a contract or grant. Paying an established per-attendee fee does not constitute (
) Symposium - A gathering of several experts in a ﬁeld at which papers are presented by specialists on subjects and discussed with a view to making ommendations. (
) Third-party event planner - An individual or an organization that is in the business of providing advice on planning, organizing, and conducting often with many participants. (

) Training - A planned, prepared and coordinated program, course, subject or program of instruction or education that improves individual and ganizational performance and helps achieve the agency’s mission and performance goals. (

) Unique internal order code (UIOC) - A ﬁve or eight-digit, alphanumeric ﬁnancial code that tracks the costs of speciﬁc events for IRS training and meetings. It is required for training or meetings with a total estimated or reimbursable cost of $
or more. (
) Workshop - A gathering for educational and/or work purposes to on deﬁned areas of concern. Workshops emphasize the exchange of ideas and the demonstration and application of techniques and skills.
Meeting - A gathering of people with a purpose to discuss business matters, which may include strategizing, planning, and resolving speciﬁc issues or

, Event Spending Approval Process, was established for business units to document the time spent preparing requests for the approval of event-related spending for ences, meetings, and training, as well as the time spent preparing for required reporting to Treasury. The SETR code is available if the unit chooses to track the time spent on event spending approval process quirements. (

) Business units administering the event spending approval process, reviewing and packaging requests for approval by the IRS or Treasury and maintaining records of event spending requests, may also use this code. (
) As required by this IRM and Executive Order
, establishing funding determining work plans are an annual process. As part of the process, all business units must include training in their work plans. (
) Each year, the business units will develop an Annual Training Plan based training needs assessment for the following ﬁscal year. (

) Embedded Learning and Education staff will meet with their business unit’s contacts and coordinators to determine their annual training resource ments and input their training plan, which includes all training, into the Servicewide Training Events Tracking System (STETS). (
) All ﬁrst quarter training events must be added to STETS by the ﬁrst day of July and include all October, November and December events. The complete Annual Training Plan is due by September
th. (

A unique internal order code (UIOC) is a ﬁve or eight-digit, alphanumeric ﬁnancial code that tracks the costs of speciﬁc events for IRS training and meetings. The UIOC is required for training or meetings with a total estimated or reimbursable cost of $
or more. Business units must contact their ﬁnance or budget office to request ment of a UIOC for events with a total estimated or reimbursable cost of $

or greater. Once an event has been approved, the CFO/FM cost will activate the established UIOC for use. Travelers must use the UIOC when attending an approved training or this ensures the IRS can capture the full cost of an event.

) The Servicewide Training and Event Tracking System (STETS) is used by STEM and business units to coordinate and manage the Service’s events. (
) The STETS also: a. tracks the Annual Training Plan and approvals of training and events; b. helps to reduce the burden on business units when completing these tasks. (
) Business units and operating divisions must enter all training and events the STETS for database tracking. However, meeting events with costs less than $
are exempt from STETS input. (
) Business units must ensure that monthly ad hoc events are marked the STETS by the ﬁrst business day of the month and meet all training and TD

requirements to be considered for ad hoc processing which includes all required supporting documentation. Note: If events are submitted and marked ready and then are found to not the correct documentation or contain errors, they will be marked as NOT READY for the business unit to correct. Events will be pulled for and approval during the subsequent month’s ad hoc cycle. (

) Business units must enter only the actual event start and end dates of the class into the STETS. Do not include travel dates for the event. Travel only apply to the itemized expense template to estimate travel.

If events are submitted and marked ready and then are found to not have the correct documentation or contain errors, they will be marked as NOT READY for the business unit to correct. Events will be pulled for processing and approval during the subsequent month’s ad hoc cycle.

Reminder: The STETS requires the use of actual class dates. Applying the travel dates for the delivery dates of the event will inﬂate the number of hours for an event and will not match up with the course length ﬁeld. On the other hand, the Service- wide Travel Estimator (STE) requires the use of actual travel dates for attendees and Instructors to generate the Itemized Expense Template (IET). The IET is completed to estimate travel; therefore, it is critical to include the actual travel dates to arrive at an accurate cost estimate of all days of travel.

approval, the ﬁelds in a locked event record may be updated, except for the cost, participant, and Objective and ROI statements.

) The expectation is that any postponed training or event will be held within one year of the originally scheduled and approved start date.
